definition[0]: happening often and to many people or in many places
example[0]: Heart disease is one of the commonest causes of death.
example[1]: It is common for children to be afraid (NOT It is common that children are afraid) of the dark.
example[2]: Bad dreams are fairly common among children.
example[3]: It’s common for new fathers to feel jealous of the baby.
note[1]: it’s common for somebody to do something
definition[2]: common aims, beliefs, ideas etc are shared by several people or groups
example[5]: people working towards a common goal
example[6]: countries that share a common language
example[7]: a theme that is common to all her novels
definition[3]: belonging to or shared by everyone in a society
example[8]: Joe was chosen as captain by common consent (=with everyone’s agreement).
example[9]: These problems are common to all societies.
definition[4]: ordinary and not special in any way
example[11]: The 20th century was called the century of the common man (=ordinary people).
example[12]: He insists that he is a revolutionary, not a common criminal.
definition[5]: an offensive word used for describing someone from a low social class
definition[6]: if something is common, there are a lot of them
example[13]: Jones is a very common name in Great Britain.
example[14]: Foxes are common in the area.
example[15]: Personal computers are nearly as common in American homes as televisions.
definition[7]: happening in a lot of places or done by a lot of people
example[16]: Racism is much more widespread than people imagine.
example[17]: The report claimed that the problem of police brutality was widespread.
definition[8]: common in a particular place or time – used especially when saying that this seems surprising or unusual
example[19]: Crimes such as robbery are commonplace in big cities.
example[20]: Expensive foreign cars are commonplace in this Chicago suburb.
definition[9]: common in a place or among a group of people – used especially about illnesses, problems, or ideas
example[21]: Flu is most prevalent during the winter months.
example[22]: Depression remains one of the most prevalent health disorders in the US.
example[23]: This belief is more prevalent among men than women.
definition[10]: very common – used about illnesses or problems
example[24]: AIDS is rife in some parts of the world.
definition[11]: very common and seen in many different places – often used humorously in written descriptions
example[25]: He was carrying the ubiquitous MP3 player.
example[26]: In Britain, CCTV cameras are ubiquitous.
definition[12]: used when saying that you can see something a lot in many different places
example[27]: Images of the dictator were everywhere.
example[28]: Microchips seem to be everywhere these days – even in washing machines.
example[29]: One of the first things you notice in Amsterdam are the bicycles – they’re everywhere.
definition[13]: a large area of open land in a town or village that people walk or play sport on
